net.hudup.core.evaluate

Class MetricWrapper

  • java.lang.Object
    • net.hudup.core.evaluate.AbstractMetric
      • net.hudup.core.evaluate.MetricWrapper
  • All Implemented Interfaces:
    java.io.Serializable, Alg, Metric

    @BaseClass
public class MetricWrapper
extends AbstractMetric
    Note, the abstract class of Metric interface is {code AbstractMetric}. Three implemented classes of Metric which inherit from AbstractMetric are DefaultMetric, MetaMetric, and MetricWrapper as follows:
    • The DefaultMetric class is default partial implementation of single Metric.
    • The MetaMetric class is a complex Metric which contains other metrics.
    • In some situations, if metric requires complicated implementation, it is wrapped by this MetricWrapper class.
    As a convention, this MetricWrapper is called metric wrapper. It contains an internal metric referred by its internal variable metric. Actually, such internal metric calculates measure for evaluating an algorithm. Moreover, metric wrapper contains additional information as follows:
    • Name of the algorithm (referred by algName) on which the internal metric metric evaluates.
    • Identifier (ID) referred by datasetId of the dataset used to evaluate the algorithm.
    • URI (referred by datasetUri) of the dataset used to evaluate the algorithm.
    Version:
    10.0
    Author:
    Loc Nguyen
    See Also:
    Serialized Form

      • getCurrentValue

        public MetricValue getCurrentValue()
        Description copied from interface: Metric
        Methods Metric.getAccumValue() and Metric.getAccumValue() return accumulative value and current value of metric. After each time metric is re-calculated by Metric.recalc(Object...) method, accumulative value and current value can be changed. For example, a sample metric receives values 3, 1, 2 at the first, second, and third calculations. At the fourth calculation if Metric.recalc(Object...) produces value 2, the Metric.getCurrentValue() will return 2 and the Metric.getAccumValue() will return 3 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 8. Methods Metric.getAccumValue() and Metric.getCurrentValue() can return any thing and so their returned value is represented by MetricValue interface. How to implement MetricValue is dependent on concrete application.
        Returns:
        current MetricValue

      • getAccumValue

        public MetricValue getAccumValue()
        Description copied from interface: Metric
        Methods Metric.getAccumValue() and Metric.getAccumValue() return accumulative value and current value of metric. After each time metric is re-calculated by Metric.recalc(Object...) method, accumulative value and current value can be changed. For example, a sample metric receives values 3, 1, 2 at the first, second, and third calculations. At the fourth calculation if Metric.recalc(Object...) produces value 2, the Metric.getCurrentValue() will return 2 and the Metric.getAccumValue() will return 3 + 1 + 2 + 2 = 8. Methods Metric.getAccumValue() and Metric.getCurrentValue() can return any thing and so their returned value is represented by MetricValue interface. How to implement MetricValue is dependent on concrete application.
        Returns:
        accumulated MetricValue

      • recalc

        public boolean recalc(java.lang.Object... params)
               throws java.lang.Exception
        Description copied from interface: Metric
        This is the most important method expressing how to re-calculate a concrete metric according to specified parameters.
        Parameters:
        params - specified array of objects known as parameters. Such parameters varied according to concrete metric.
        Returns:
        whether calculating successfully
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - if any error raises.

      • create

        public static MetricWrapper create(Metric metric,
                                   java.lang.String algName,
                                   int datasetId,
                                   xURI datasetUri)
        Creating a metric wrapper with specified internal metric, algorithm name, identifier of dataset, and URI of dataset. This method is used to construct a metric wrapper.
        Parameters:
        metric - specified internal metric actually calculates measure for evaluating an algorithm.
        algName - specified name of the algorithm on which the internal metric evaluates.
        datasetId - specified identifier (ID) of the dataset used to evaluate the algorithm.
        datasetUri - specified URI of the dataset used to evaluate the algorithm.
        Returns:
        new metric wrapper with specified internal metric, algorithm name, identifier of dataset, and URI of dataset.
